sn13.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn13.1:4.3: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt under his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:
sn13.1:4.4: “What do you think, mendicants? Which is more: the little bit of dirt under my fingernail, or this great earth?”
sn13.1:5.1: “Sir, the great earth is far more.
sn13.1:5.2: The little bit of dirt under your fingernail is tiny.
sn13.1:5.3: Compared to the great earth, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.”
sn13.1:5.4: “In the same way, for a noble disciple accomplished in view, a person with comprehension, the suffering that’s over and done with is more,
sn13.1:5.6: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it’s not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part, since there’s at most seven more lives.
sn13.1:5.7: That’s how very beneficial it is to comprehend the teaching
sn13.1:5.8: and gain the vision of the teaching.”
